verses.text: Do not desire to be friends with many, and do not be quick to embrace everyone.
verses.comment: This begins a reflection on genuine friendship. Later verses affirm the value of faithful companions. The caution here echoes Proverbs 18:24 (Prov. 18:24), warning against superficial relationships.

verses.text: For by being too intimate, you may become entangled, and fall into disgrace.
verses.comment: A concern for honor and prudence in relationships. The 'entanglement' is moral and social, hinting at wisdom's protective role.

verses.text: If your enemies hear about it, they will mock you, and will never stop slandering you.
verses.comment: Consequences of imprudence are social, not just personal. Keeping one's affairs private preserves reputation.

verses.text: Have you ever fallen into the hands of a friend who turns against you? Then pray that God will protect you.
verses.comment: True friends are rare. Trust must be combined with prayer and discernment. Christ's example of trusting the Father and selecting disciples is a spiritual parallel (John 15:13–15).

verses.text: Give no place to scandal and do not speak deceitfully.
verses.comment: Speech is to be measured. This reflects the wisdom in James 3:5–10 (James 3:5–10) on speaking carefully.

verses.text: Let your acquaintance be many, but your confidant one in a thousand.
verses.comment: A principle of discernment: many acquaintances, but deep trust reserved for a tried companion. Jesus' choosing of the apostles mirrors this (Luke 6:12–13).

verses.text: When you find a friend, test him first, and do not be too quick to trust him.
verses.comment: Trust is earned through patience. The testing of friendship calls to mind the testing of faith in 1 Thess. 5:21 (1 Thess. 5:21).

verses.text: For some are friends in times of prosperity, but will not remain in trouble.
verses.comment: Conditional friendship is warning against. Compare to Proverbs 19:6–7 (Prov. 19:6–7).

verses.text: There are friends who turn into enemies and reveal your quarrels to disgrace you.
verses.comment: A transition from false friends to genuine loyalty. Betrayal echoes Judas's betrayal of Christ (Matt. 26:47–50).

verses.text: There are friends who share in your table, but will not stand by you in your distress.
verses.comment: Superficial friendship is contrasted here with faithful companionship. The table motif is prophetic of the Last Supper.

verses.text: If you are successful, they are like you; but in adversity, they stand apart from you.
verses.comment: The reality of fair-weather friends. True spiritual unity requires loyalty, as Christ's disciples are called to remain with Him even in suffering.

verses.text: Do not trust your enemy forever; for as rust corrodes iron, so wickedness corrupts the heart.
verses.comment: Evil is described as corrosive. A call to vigilance.

verses.text: Even if an enemy humbles himself and walks with bowed head, be careful and guard yourself from him.
verses.comment: Caution not to confuse outward appearance with genuine repentance. The spiritual interpretation warns against false conversions.

verses.text: Faithful friends are a safe refuge; whoever finds one has found a treasure.
verses.comment: True friendship is described as a spiritual blessing. The language hints at the sacramental bonds found in the community of believers (Ps. 133:1).

verses.text: A faithful friend is beyond price; nothing equals his worth.
verses.comment: Portrays faithful friendship as inestimable, reflecting the value God places on charity and true unity.

verses.text: A faithful friend is a medicine for life; those who fear the Lord will find one.
verses.comment: Friendship brings healing. 'Fear of the Lord' links faithfulness to God with the blessing of friendship.

verses.text: Those who fear the Lord will direct their friendships rightly, because as he is, so will his friend be.
verses.comment: Spiritual friendship reflects God's love. The spiritual interpretation suggests unity of will and communion with God, echoing John 15:12 (John 15:12).

verses.text: My child, from your youth choose instruction, and you will find wisdom even in old age.
verses.comment: Early formation in wisdom leads to lasting fruit. Spiritual interpretation: lifelong discipleship.

verses.text: Come to her as a worker and a sower, and wait patiently for her good fruits.
verses.comment: 'Her' refers to wisdom personified as a woman. Waiting alludes to perseverance (see James 5:7 James 5:7).

verses.text: For while cultivating her, you will labor little, but soon you will eat of her produce.
verses.comment: A promise of reward for diligence. Wisdom yields abundant fruit. Echoes the teaching on sowing and reaping in 2 Cor. 9:6 (2 Cor. 9:6).

verses.text: She is harsh at first to the ignorant, and does not reveal herself to the foolish.
verses.comment: Wisdom requires humility and effort, not ease or instant gratification. Compare Prov. 1:7 (Prov. 1:7).

verses.text: She will put her burden upon him until she tests him with her decrees.
verses.comment: Wisdom tests and disciplines; the spiritual parallel is the formation of saints through trials.

verses.text: Then she will return him to the right path and reveal her secrets to him.
verses.comment: Initiation into wisdom includes both trial and revelation. Spiritual growth involves gradual enlightenment.

verses.text: If you stray, she will reject you and turn you over to your own ruin.
verses.comment: Abandoning wisdom leads to ruin. The principle of sowing and reaping is upheld.

verses.text: Watch for opportunities to learn and do not neglect instruction.
verses.comment: Encouragement to remain teachable. Compare Prov. 8:34 (Prov. 8:34).

verses.text: If you love hearing, you will become wise; if you listen, your understanding will grow.
verses.comment: A call to love learning and be open to truth. Spiritual growth requires humility.

verses.text: Stand with the gathering of elders, and cling to their wisdom.
verses.comment: Learning in community and from elders is encouraged. The concept of apostolic succession is subtly echoed, as wisdom is handed down.

verses.text: Be eager to listen to every godly discourse, and do not let wise sayings escape you.
verses.comment: The oral transmission of wisdom is valued. Compare Deut. 6:6–7 (Deut. 6:6–7).

verses.text: If you see an intelligent man, rise early to find him, and let your foot wear out his doorstep.
verses.comment: Pursuit of wisdom requires effort and humility.

verses.text: Study the words of God and meditate on his commandments.
verses.comment: Personal meditation and devotion. Compare Ps. 119:15 (Ps. 119:15).

verses.text: He will establish your heart, and wisdom will be your counselor.
verses.comment: God's indwelling presence guides the heart. Spiritual interpretation: the guidance of the Holy Spirit.

verses.text: If you desire wisdom, keep the commandments, and the Lord will give her to you.
verses.comment: Obedience is linked to receiving wisdom. Shows that Grace works through observance, not just faith alone.

verses.text: Fear the Lord and seek wisdom with sincerity.
verses.comment: True fear of the Lord is reverence and leads to spiritual growth.

verses.text: If you seek her, she will be found; if you hold to her, do not let her go.
verses.comment: Persistence is rewarded. Wisdom is portrayed as 'her' in a maternal role, recalling Prov. 3:18 (Prov. 3:18).

verses.text: For in the end you will rest in her, and she will turn your sorrow into joy.
verses.comment: Wisdom brings consolation. The tradition of spiritual joy through union with wisdom.

verses.text: Within wisdom, you will become wise yourself, and you will be praised by all who know you.
verses.comment: Consistent with the biblical view that wisdom brings honor. Compare Daniel 12:3 (Dan. 12:3).

verses.text: Draw near to wisdom and remain close to her, so that you may be taught the fear of the Lord, and your heart may be enlightened.
verses.comment: Ends with the exhortation to remain close to Wisdom. Spiritual meaning: discipleship, formation through devotion, and openness to enlightenment. Echoes New Testament calls to 'abide in Christ' (John 15:4).
